item.title: Pentagon Races to Spend $153 Billion in Added Funds for Military
item.description: The Trump administration for months ignored Congress’s demand for a plan on how the Defense Department would spend the money that Republicans pushed through in their sweeping domestic policy bill.
item.dc:creator: Megan Mineiro
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
item.media:description: A Defense Department report to Congress detailed a range of priorities for extra funding, including purchasing over a dozen new ships, enhancing weapons manufacturing and integrating artificial intelligence into the military’s capabilities.

item.title: Trump Says General Caine Sees Easy Victory if U.S. Attacks Iran
item.description: The remarks differ from what Gen. Dan Caine, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, is said to have told the president in high-level White House meetings.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gen. Dan Caine, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, in December. President Trump has been leaning toward conducting an initial strike against Iran in coming days intended to demonstrate to the country’s leaders that they must be willing to agree to give up the ability to make a nuclear weapon.

item.title: Pentagon Pulls Support for Air Safety Bill Written After D.C. Helicopter and Plane Crash
item.description: The legislation, which the House is expected to vote on Tuesday, would require military and commercial aircraft to use certain tracking technology to avoid collisions.
item.dc:creator: Karoun Demirjian
item.media:credit: Kent Nishimura for The New York Times
item.media:description: The bill would force a safety review of flight routes at all large and midsize airports, including Ronald Reagan National Airport in Arlington, Va.

item.title: Five Big Political Questions About Trump’s State of the Union Speech
item.description: Tariffs, the cost of living, immigration: The president has a careful line to walk on major issues.
item.dc:creator: Katie Glueck
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times

item.title: ‘A Long Speech’: Trump Prepares for State of the Union
item.description: President Trump does not like to practice reading the speech out loud, but he spent time mimicking the setup of the House chamber, officials familiar with his plans said.
item.dc:creator: Tyler Pager
item.media:credit: Eric Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: A TV screen showed President Trump’s address to a joint session of Congress at the Capitol last March.

item.title: Pentagon Summons Anthropic Chief in Dispute Over A.I. Limits
item.description: The artificial intelligence company has demanded that some guardrails be put in place as it negotiates a contract with the Defense Department.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes and Sheera Frenkel
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dario Amodei, the chief executive of Anthropic, will meet with Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth at the Pentagon.

item.title: U.S. Hits Another Boat in the Caribbean, Killing 3
item.description: The Defense Department did not provide evidence of its claim that the vessel was carrying drugs. At least 150 people have been killed in the campaign since September.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt

item.title: ‘Angel Families’ Return to Washington to Back Up Trump Ahead of State of the Union
item.description: The families of people killed by undocumented immigrants have forged a bond with the president, who has invited some of them to his address on Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: Katie Rogers
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump gathered several families at the White House on Monday to sign a proclamation honoring people who had been killed by undocumented immigrants on Monday.

item.title: Johnson Will Bring Daughter of Jimmy Lai to State of the Union Address
item.description: Her appearance underscores that “America is determined” to secure the release of the Hong Kong democracy activist, Speaker Mike Johnson said.
item.dc:creator: Catie Edmondson
item.media:credit: Julia Demaree Nikhinson/Associated Press
item.media:description: Claire Lai, the daughter of Jimmy Lai, who was blamed by China for masterminding Hong Kong’s major protests nearly seven years ago, has called her father’s imprisonment “heartbreakingly cruel.”

item.title: Facing Angry ‘MAHA Moms,’ Kennedy Defends Trump’s Pesticide Order
item.description: Health Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. angered supporters last week by backing an order to ramp up production of the weedkiller glyphosate.
item.dc:creator: Sheryl Gay Stolberg
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
item.media:description: Health Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. said he would push for a food system that was less reliant on chemicals.

item.title: Border Patrol Shoots Armed Person Near Canadian Border, Authorities Say
item.description: The F.B.I. said that the person, who was not killed, “allegedly fired at” a Border Patrol agent in Pittsburg, N.H., around 1 a.m. on Sunday.
item.dc:creator: Madeleine Ngo
item.media:credit: John Tully for The New York Times
item.media:description: Outside the town of Pittsburg, N.H, in 2024. Federal authorities said that a Border Patrol agent shot an armed individual near the Canadian border in Pittsburg early on Sunday.

item.title: Training for New ICE Agents Is ‘Deficient’ and ‘Broken,’ Whistle-Blower Says
item.description: The former official appeared with congressional Democrats, who also released documents indicating significant reductions in instructional hours for recruits.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Nehamas and Hamed Aleaziz
item.category: Senate Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
item.media:description: “For the last five months, I watched ICE dismantle the training program,” Ryan Schwank told congressional Democrats on Monday.

item.title: Another C.D.C. Vaccine Skeptic Steps Down
item.description: Dr. Ralph Abraham, the agency’s principal deputy director, has called the Covid vaccines “dangerous.” Other skeptics have recently left federal health roles.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Hilary Scheinuk/The Advocate, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Dr. Ralph Abraham resigned less than three months into the job.

item.title: Peter Mandelson, Ex-Ambassador to the U.S., Is Released After U.K. Arrest Amid Epstein Accusations
item.description: Peter Mandelson was arrested on Monday on suspicion of “misconduct in public office” following revelations about his dealings with Jeffrey Epstein, the sex offender.
item.dc:creator: Lizzie Dearden and Stephen Castle
item.media:credit: Reuters

item.title: Alex Padilla Plans Spanish Rebuttal to Trump’s State of the Union
item.description: Senator Alex Padilla, a Democrat from California, offered a preview of his remarks, which he expects to focus on the economy, immigration and fair elections.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Medina
item.media:credit: Heather Diehl/Getty Images
item.media:description: Senator Alex Padilla of California is set to give the Democratic Party’s Spanish-language rebuttal to President Trump’s State of the Union address.

item.title: Trump Administration Scrambles to Pick Up the Pieces of Broken Tariffs
item.description: President Trump is already working to piece his tariff program back together, after a Supreme Court ruling ruptured a centerpiece of his economic agenda.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump has said that tariffs will help America’s manufacturing sector and create factory jobs, though many economists have questioned those claims.

item.title: Trump-Appointed Judge Bars Release of Jack Smith’s Report in Documents Case
item.description: Judge Aileen Cannon, a Trump-appointed federal judge in Florida, slammed the former special counsel, Jack Smith, for drafting the report even after she had dismissed the case.
item.dc:creator: Alan Feuer
item.category: Federal Criminal Case Against Trump (Documents Case)
item.media:credit: Joe Raedle/Getty Images
item.media:description: The ruling by the judge, Aileen M. Cannon, was her latest effort in the past several months to keep the public from seeing Jack Smith’s sprawling report.

item.title: ‘Survivor’ Is America
item.description: It’s our greatest game and our truest mirror. And in its tiki-torch-festooned way, it’s captured our society as an ever-changing collection of tribes.
item.dc:creator: James Poniewozik

item.title: Top Fed Official Sees Little Effect on Rate Outlook From Supreme Court’s Tariff Ruling
item.description: Christopher J. Waller, a Federal Reserve governor, said he would support a pause in rate cuts in March if the labor market continued to show signs of stabilizing.
item.dc:creator: Colby Smith
item.media:credit: Brendan McDermid/Reuters
item.media:description: Christopher J. Waller, a governor at the Fed, on Monday acknowledged the extreme uncertainty around President Trump’s tariffs.

item.title: Fact-Check: Trump’s Latest Claims on Jobs, Inflation and Crime
item.description: Trends on jobs, inflation and crime that began before Donald Trump retook office continued, largely unabated, in his first year back.
item.dc:creator: Ashley Cai and Linda Qiu
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump speaking in Rome, Ga., last week.

item.title: Judges Grow Angry Over Trump Administration Violating Their Orders
item.description: At least 35 times since August, federal judges have ordered the administration to explain why it should not be punished for violating their orders in immigration cases.
item.dc:creator: Mattathias Schwartz, Zach Montague and Ernesto Londoño
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: In internal communications, the Justice Department’s leadership in Washington has taken a defiant posture toward federal judges.

item.title: Former F.B.I. Official, Ousted Under Trump, Will Run for Congress in Maryland
item.description: David Sundberg, who led the Washington Field Office, is joining a crowded Democratic primary for Steny H. Hoyer’s open House seat.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage
item.media:credit: Carolyn Van Houten for The New York Times
item.media:description: David Sundberg said he had decided to run for Congress after becoming dismayed at how President Trump was directing the F.B.I. and the Justice Department to investigate and prosecute his perceived political enemies.

item.title: Supreme Court Considers Fate of Docks and Other Assets Seized by Cuba in 1960
item.description: Amid rising tensions with Cuba, the Trump administration is backing lawsuits that would allow Americans to get compensation for property confiscated by Fidel Castro’s regime.
item.dc:creator: Ann E. Marimow
item.media:credit: Havana Docks Company
item.media:description: Revolutionaries confiscated the property of the Havana Docks Company in 1960.

item.title: Democrats Consider Breaking a Taboo in Washington State: A Millionaires Tax
item.description: The state where Jeff Bezos and Bill Gates made fortunes might have progressive social policies, but its resistance to an income tax is similar to conservative states. That might change.
item.dc:creator: Anna Griffin
